arm_group.description: Standard treatment for acne scars followed by suction.
Standard treatment for acne scars only

brief_summary.textblock:
The primary objective of this study is to determine whether the use of standard treatment in
      conjunction with suction will improve acne scars compared to a standard treatment alone.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Subcision and Suction on Acne Scars

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Age 18 and over

          -  Have bilateral rolling acne scars

          -  Are in good health

          -  Subject has the willingness and ability to understand and provide informed consent
             for the use of their tissue and communicate with the investigator.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Under 18 years of age

          -  Pregnancy or lactation

          -  Unable to understand the protocol or give informed consent

          -  Has mental illness

          -  Recent Accutane use in the past 6 months

          -  Prone to hypertrophic and keloidal scarring

facility.name: Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Department of Dermatology

clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Split Face Randomized, Evaluator Blinded Study on the Effect of Subcision and Suctioning With a Microdermabrasion Device on Rolling Acne Scars

primary_outcome.description: The change in acne scarring is measured using a global scarring grading system to compare baseline scarring to the treatments.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in acne scarring compared to baseline after treatments

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor in Dermatology, Otolaryngology- Head and Neck Surgery, and Surgery-Organ Transplantation

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
